title: Chemotherapy-Induced Peripheral Neuropathy (CIPN)
icd10: T45.1X5A (Adverse effect of antineoplastic and immunosuppressive drugs
scope: ** Evaluation and management of peripheral neuropathy caused by or attributed to chemotherapy agents in adults. Includes identification of causative agents, grading severity, dose modification guidance, symptomatic treatment, and long-term monitoring. Covers outpatient screening and management during active chemotherapy, inpatient evaluation for acute neurotoxicity, and post-treatment chronic neuropathy. Excludes radiation-induced neuropathy and paraneoplastic neuropathy as separate entities (addressed in differential).

Core Labs (Exclude Concurrent Neuropathy.rationale: Diabetes is most common concurrent cause of neuropathy in cancer patients; must exclude as contributor
Core Labs (Exclude Concurrent Neuropathy.target: <6.5%; if elevated, concurrent diabetic neuropathy likely contributing

Core Labs (Exclude Concurrent Neuropathy.rationale: Screen for diabetes; steroid-induced hyperglycemia common in chemo regimens
B12 deficiency common in cancer patients (poor nutrition, metformin use); worsens neuropathy
Renal function (cisplatin nephrotoxicity); electrolytes (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia worsening neuropathy)
Core Labs (Exclude Concurrent Neuropathy.target: Normal creatinine; Mg >1.8 mg/dL; K >3.5 mEq/L

Core Labs (Exclude Concurrent Neuropathy.rationale: Hypothyroidism causes neuropathy and is common in cancer patients (checkpoint inhibitor thyroiditis)
Cisplatin and cetuximab cause renal magnesium wasting; hypomagnesemia exacerbates neuropathy and neurotoxicity

Extended Labs (When CIPN Diagnosis Uncer.rationale: Screen for paraproteinemia (myeloma patients on bortezomib may have paraprotein-associated neuropathy as well)
Extended Labs (When CIPN Diagnosis Uncer.target: No M-spike; normal free light chains

Extended Labs (When CIPN Diagnosis Uncer.rationale: Deficiency in cancer patients with poor nutrition; contributes to neuropathy and macrocytosis
Confirm B12 deficiency if borderline B12 level (200-400 pg/mL)
Copper deficiency neuropathy from zinc supplementation or malabsorption in cancer patients
Inflammatory process; vasculitic neuropathy in differential

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Paraneoplastic neuropathy mimicking CIPN; especially if neuropathy precedes or is disproportionate to chemotherapy exposure
Autoimmune neuropathy; especially if demyelinating features on EMG not expected from chemotherapy type
Document platinum accumulation in refractory cases; research tool primarily
Rare/Specialized.target: Correlate with cumulative dose and symptom severity

Essential Studies.timing: Baseline before chemotherapy (ideal); at onset of symptoms; monitor serially during treatment
Essential Studies.target: Reduced SNAP amplitudes (axonal sensory neuropathy); normal or mildly reduced NCV; denervation if motor involvement; pattern consistent with agent type
Essential Studies.contraindications: None significant (relative: thrombocytopenia for needle EMG — platelet count >20K)

Essential Studies.item: CIPN screening questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-CIPN20 or FACT/GOG-Ntx)
Essential Studies.timing: Each chemotherapy cycle; standardized patient-reported outcome measure
Essential Studies.target: Score trending; identify grade >=2 symptoms early for dose modification

Extended Studies.item: Skin biopsy (IENFD — intraepidermal nerve fiber density) (CPT 88305)
Extended Studies.timing: If small fiber neuropathy suspected (normal EMG/NCS with symptoms); quantify small fiber damage
Extended Studies.target: Reduced IENFD below age/sex-specific norms at distal leg (confirms small fiber neuropathy)

Extended Studies.timing: Research and clinical quantification of thermal and vibration thresholds; serial monitoring
Extended Studies.target: Elevated thermal/vibration detection thresholds; correlate with clinical severity

Extended Studies.timing: If myelopathy or radiculopathy suspected; metastatic disease as alternative cause of neurologic symptoms
Extended Studies.target: No cord compression, metastatic disease, or radiation-induced changes

Rare/Specialized.timing: Rarely indicated; vasculitic neuropathy suspected; atypical presentation not explained by chemotherapy
Rare/Specialized.target: Axonal degeneration pattern; vasculitis on biopsy if present
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Permanent sensory loss at biopsy site; coagulopathy

Rare/Specialized.timing: Non-invasive small fiber assessment; research tool for CIPN monitoring
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced corneal nerve fiber density and length correlating with CIPN severity

Acute Management.indication: Grade 2 CIPN (moderate symptoms limiting instrumental ADLs)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dose reduction of offending chemotherapy Per protocol Protocol

dosing.instructions: Reduce offending agent dose by 25-50% per institutional guidelines; specific agent protocols vary (e.g., oxaliplatin: 25% reduction for grade 2, discontinue for grade 3)
dosing.orderSentence: Dose reduction of offending chemotherapy Per protocol Protocol

Acute Management.contraindications: Oncology team decision balancing neuropathy risk vs cancer treatment efficacy
Acute Management.monitoring: CTCAE grading each cycle; symptom questionnaire; functional assessment

doseOptions.orderSentence: Discontinuation of offending chemotherapy Discontinue Protocol

dosing.instructions: Stop offending agent; consider alternative non-neurotoxic regimen; oncology decision weighing risk-benefit
dosing.orderSentence: Discontinuation of offending chemotherapy Discontinue Protocol

Acute Management.monitoring: Symptom monitoring for coasting phenomenon (platinum agents); cancer treatment response

Acute Management.indication: Acute cold-triggered paresthesias during/after oxaliplatin infusion

doseOptions.text: 1 g calcium gluconate + 1 g magnesium sulfate
doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium/magnesium infusion (for oxaliplatin acute neuropathy) 1 g calcium gluconate + 1 g magnesium sulfate IV

dosing.instructions: 1 g calcium gluconate + 1 g MgSO4 in 100 mL NS IV over 30 min before and after oxaliplatin infusion; reduces acute neurotoxicity
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium/magnesium infusion (for oxaliplatin acute neuropathy) 1 g calcium gluconate + 1 g magnesium sulfate IV

Acute Management.contraindications: Hypercalcemia; hypermagnesemia; renal failure (dose adjust Mg)
Acute Management.monitoring: Calcium level; magnesium level; renal function

Acute Management.indication: Acute cold-triggered dysesthesia during oxaliplatin infusion

dosing.instructions: Avoid cold drinks, cold foods, and cold air exposure for 3-5 days after infusion; wear gloves for refrigerator; warm beverages only

Acute Management.indication: Cisplatin or cetuximab-induced hypomagnesemia exacerbating neuropathy

dosing.instructions: Magnesium oxide 400-800 mg daily PO; or MgSO4 2 g IV over 1 hour for severe deficiency (<1.2 mg/dL)

Acute Management.monitoring: Serum Mg q1-4 weeks; renal function; bowel habits (diarrhea)

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).indication: Neuropathic pain from CIPN; only agent with RCT evidence specifically for CIPN (ASCO recommended)

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily for 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; trial 4-8 weeks at therapeutic dose; max 120 mg/day; taper when discontinuing

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma; CrCl <30
Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).monitoring: BP (hypertension risk); hepatic function; serotonin syndrome; discontinuation syndrome; suicidality monitoring

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).indication: Neuropathic pain; burning/tingling; first-line alternative to duloxetine

dosing.instructions: Start 100-300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q3-7 days; target 300-600 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day; dose adjust for renal impairment

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); concurrent opioid use increases respiratory depression risk
Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; renal function for dose adjustment

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).indication: Neuropathic pain; alternative to gabapentin with more predictable pharmacokinetics

dosing.instructions: Start 50-75 mg BID; titrate to 150-300 mg BID; max 600 mg/day; dose adjust for renal impairment

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).monitoring: Weight gain; peripheral edema; sedation; renal dosing

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).indication: Localized neuropathic pain; feet predominantly; patients intolerant of systemic medications

dosing.instructions: Applied by healthcare professional to affected area for 30-60 minutes; may repeat q3 months; pre-treat with topical lidocaine

Symptomatic Treatment (First-Line).monitoring: Skin reaction at application site (burning, erythema); BP monitoring during application (transient increase)

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: CIPN pain refractory to duloxetine; some evidence for acute oxaliplatin neuropathy prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily; titrate to 75-150 mg daily; extended release preferred; taper when discontinuing

Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: BP; serotonin syndrome; discontinuation syndrome; QTc if high dose

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Neuropathic pain; sleep disruption from neuropathy; adjunct therapy

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg qHS; titrate by 10 mg q1-2 weeks; max 50 mg qHS for neuropathic pain; avoid in elderly

Second-Line/Refractory.indication: Refractory CIPN pain; emerging evidence; non-pharmacologic

dosing.instructions: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (walking, cycling) plus balance and resistance training; supervised initially; improves nerve function and reduces fall risk

Neuroprotective Agents (Limited Evidence.monitoring: Functional capacity; fall risk; compliance; pain levels

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for electrodiagnostic testing (EMG/NCS), CIPN confirmation, and to rule out concurrent neuropathy etiologies (diabetic, B12, paraneoplastic)
Physical therapy for balance training, fall prevention, gait assessment, and exercise program — fall risk is elevated in CIPN patients
Occupational therapy for hand function assessment, adaptive devices, and fine motor rehabilitation if hand involvement affects ADLs
Pain management specialist for refractory CIPN pain not responding to duloxetine/gabapentin; multimodal approach
Oncology discussion regarding dose modification, alternative regimens, and treatment goals when CIPN reaches grade 2 or higher
Podiatry referral for foot care, custom orthotics, and fall prevention assessment — sensory loss increases foot injury risk

Patient Instructions.item: Report numbness, tingling, or burning in hands or feet to the oncology team before each chemotherapy cycle — early detection allows dose adjustment to prevent irreversible damage
For oxaliplatin patients: avoid cold drinks, cold food, cold air, and touching cold surfaces for 3-5 days after each infusion; use gloves when opening the refrigerator or freezer
Use fall prevention measures: wear well-fitting shoes with non-slip soles; use nightlights; remove loose rugs; install grab bars in bathroom; use handrails on stairs
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or injuries — reduced sensation means you may not feel foot injuries; diabetic-type foot care reduces complications
Avoid alcohol which has its own neurotoxic effects and can worsen chemotherapy-induced neuropathy

Understand that some neuropathy symptoms may worsen ("coasting") for weeks to months after stopping chemotherapy (especially platinum drugs) before stabilizing — this is expected and not a sign of cancer progression
Exercise regularly (walking, cycling, swimming) as tolerated — exercise has been shown to improve nerve function, balance, and quality of life in CIPN patients

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain adequate nutrition: balanced diet with B vitamins, folate, and protein to support nerve health during chemotherapy
Optimize glucose control if diabetic (HbA1c <7%) — uncontrolled diabetes significantly worsens CIPN severity and recovery
Replace magnesium and electrolyte deficiencies promptly — cisplatin and cetuximab deplete magnesium which exacerbates neurotoxicity
Engage in regular moderate exercise (30 min, 3-5x/week) during and after chemotherapy — emerging evidence supports exercise as both neuroprotective and therapeutic for CIPN
Smoking cessation — smoking impairs nerve repair and worsens neuropathy outcomes
Use assistive devices as needed (buttoning aids, grip enhancers, adapted utensils) to maintain independence during hand neuropathy

differential.features: Pre-existing diabetes; symptoms may predate chemotherapy; symmetric length-dependent; HbA1c elevated
differential.tests: HbA1c; glucose tolerance test; pre-chemo EMG baseline (if available)

differential.features: Macrocytosis; subacute combined degeneration if severe; may coexist with CIPN
differential.tests: Serum B12; methylmalonic acid; MRI spine if myelopathy

differential.features: Subacute onset; may precede cancer diagnosis; asymmetric or sensory ganglionopathy pattern; ataxia prominent
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibody panel; CSF analysis; pattern may not be length-dependent

differential.features: History of radiation field involving nerves/plexus; delayed onset (months-years post-radiation); myokymia on EMG
differential.tests: EMG showing myokymia (suggests radiation); MRI of affected plexus; temporal relationship to radiation field

differential.features: Demyelinating pattern on EMG (prolonged distal latencies, conduction block); proximal and distal weakness; CSF protein elevated
differential.tests: EMG/NCS showing demyelinating features; CSF protein; response to IVIg/steroids

differential.features: Asymmetric (mononeuritis multiplex); painful; elevated ESR/CRP; systemic vasculitis features
differential.tests: ESR/CRP; ANCA; nerve biopsy showing vasculitis; skin/renal involvement

differential.features: Family history; pes cavus; high arched feet; slowly progressive; very slow NCV; present before chemotherapy
differential.tests: Genetic testing; family history; EMG showing very slow uniform NCV

differential.features: Temporal relationship to other medications: metformin, statins, colchicine, isoniazid, linezolid
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; improvement with drug withdrawal

differential.features: History of chronic alcohol use; nutritional deficiency; may coexist
differential.tests: Alcohol use history; nutritional labs (thiamine, B12, folate); liver function

differential.features: Dermatomal pattern; unilateral; spine pain; motor and sensory deficit in specific root distribution
differential.tests: MRI spine; EMG showing radicular pattern (not length-dependent)

monitoring.item: CIPN screening questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-CIPN20 or FACT/GOG-Ntx)
monitoring.action: Dose reduce or discontinue chemotherapy per protocol; intensify symptom management
Grade 2: dose reduce 25-50%; Grade 3: hold or discontinue; discuss with oncology

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (strength, sensation, reflexes, gait, Romberg)
monitoring.frequency: Each oncology visit; each neurology visit
monitoring.action: Adjust chemotherapy; add symptomatic treatment; PT referral for balance

monitoring.frequency: Baseline (pre-chemo ideal); at onset of symptoms; q6-12 months during treatment
monitoring.action: SNAP amplitude drop >50% → consider dose modification; new denervation → urgent oncology discussion
PT referral; home safety evaluation; assistive device assessment; reduce sedating medications

monitoring.frequency: Each chemo cycle; weekly during cisplatin
monitoring.action: Replace IV MgSO4 if <1.2; oral supplementation if 1.2-1.8; dose may need to be held
Cisplatin dose adjustment per renal function; hold if significant decline

disposition.criteria: Acute CIPN exacerbation with stable neurologic exam; pain controlled with oral medications; no fall-related injuries requiring admission; neurology/oncology follow-up arranged
Acute neurologic decline requiring serial exams; fall with injury needing workup; severe electrolyte derangement (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia) requiring IV replacement

Severe (grade 3) CIPN with inability to perform self-care; cisplatin nephrotoxicity with electrolyte crisis; fall with injury requiring inpatient management; acute chemotherapy reaction requiring monitoring
Rare; only if concurrent chemotherapy toxicity (severe nephrotoxicity, sepsis in neutropenic patient); respiratory compromise from vinca alkaloid-induced autonomic/motor neuropathy
Before each chemotherapy cycle: CIPN screening; dose modification decisions; ongoing monitoring during active treatment
Initial evaluation: 2-4 weeks after symptom onset; EMG/NCS baseline; follow-up q3-6 months during treatment; post-treatment monitoring for coasting q3 months for 1 year
